text: hi students how are you this is an
introduction to coordinate
conjunctions and when I like to think of
coordinate conjunctions I like to
compare them to either mathematics or
chemistry I know there's a you know few
students out there that don't enjoy uh
grammar but I like to make that
comparison just to to kind of see if
maybe you can see that formula that I
can see in writing so your sentence
combining workbook will introduce you to
coordinate conjunctions what follows is
an introduction to compound sentences so
that way you can try to see a formula in
writing so to write a a compound
sentence you will use a seven coordinate
conjunctions but or yet so for and a nor
you can memorize a short list of
coordinate conjunctions by remembering
the acronym Bo friend or or F
boys so I'm telling you that coordinate
conjunctions serve kind of like a plus
sign and this is the structure of the
compound
sentence so you have to have a
subject you have to have a
verb and you have to include a comma
before the coordinate
conjunction and then you have to add
another subject and another verb so this
is your pattern subject plus verb plus
the coordinate conjunction plus the
subject plus the
verb so let's look at a couple examples
of coordinate conjunctions in what I
call compound
sentences so we have the first
example I love
reading comma but my passion is writing
so you have to remember that pattern
the comma before the butt when you have
a subject and verb on both sides so here
we
have a subject I we have a verb love you
have your coordinate conjunction comma
but and then you have your subject and
then you have your complete verb in this
placee it's a helping verb and the main
verb so we have my passion is writing in
the second
example I also have the same pattern for
compound sentence where you use a
cornate conjunction to join two
sentences and this one
says I will publish my novel comma and
then I will write a children's book so
you see that same pattern here we have a
subject the verb the coordinate
conjunction comma and and then your
subject and your verb in my last in my
last sentence that I use as an example I
also use a subject and verb a coordinate
conjunction and also a subject and verb
and then this one says manat loves
basketball comma but his favorite sport
is soccer let's look at a few more
examples notice that we have the
compound sentence although the book
doesn't introduce you to the semicolon I
want to show you that it's basically the
same idea so anytime you want to use a
cornic conjunction you can also use a
semicolon instead but you have to
remember that we use the semicolon
sparingly so I have the same sentences
but notice that I have a
semicolon I have the same exact
sentence in the second example and it's
joined by a
semicolon and the same thing for my
third example I have a semicolon that
joins the
sentences okay so now what I want you to
do is I want you to go to your sentence
combining workbook and go ahead and do
the homework you're going to focus on
odd numbers um and then we're going to
be doing a Wiki
activity and I expect you to apply those
rules to your writing and also look for
those sentence patterns in whatever it
is that you're reading for fun let it be
a magazine a novel a textbook look for
those patterns and you will be and you
will improve your own writing style and
that's that thank you
